content.full_text: Account of William Odam to James Rutledge, [1831]1 [Table 1]
paragraphs: Account of William Odam to James Rutledge, [1831]1
[Table 1: 1830&18312 | To 1 years boarding while carrying the mail $27—00...]
citations:
Sangamo Journal(Springfield, IL), 1 December 1831, 3:5; William Odom probate case file 89, Sangamon
                     County Probate Court records, Illinois Regional Archives Depository (IRAD), University
                     of Illinois-Springfield.
Benjamin P. Thomas,Lincoln's New Salem(Springfield, IL: Abraham Lincoln Association, 1934), 7.

footnotes.text:
1Page one of this document is entirely in Abraham Lincoln’s handwriting, aside from
                  James Rutledge’s and Bowling Green’s signatures.Odam’s will was entered into probate January 4, 1831; by December 1831, the estate
                  was in the final stages of settlement. This account was likely written during that
                  period.Sangamo Journal(Springfield, IL), 1 December 1831, 3:5; William Odom probate case file 89, Sangamon
                     County Probate Court records, Illinois Regional Archives Depository (IRAD), University
                     of Illinois-Springfield.

2While living inNew Salem, Lincoln frequently wrote various documents for his friends and neighbors. This account
                  was likely related to the time when Rutledge turned his home into a tavern for boarders.Benjamin P. Thomas,Lincoln's New Salem(Springfield, IL: Abraham Lincoln Association, 1934), 7.
